block.para: The central result of this section is the following geometrical interpretation of the determinant operation.

cell.para: Theorem – Let \Vect{x}_1, \dots , \Vect{x}_n be n vectors in \RNr[n], and write them as column vectors. Then

block.para: In the formula above, \omega( \Vect{x}_1 , \dots , \Vect{x}_n ) denotes the orientation of \RNr[n] represented by the n-tuple of vectors ( \Vect{x}_1 , \dots , \Vect{x}_n ). This is +1 if the orientation is positive, and it is -1 if the orientation is negative. Finally, \Vol( \Vect{x}_1 , \dots , \Vect{x}_n ) denotes the volume of the slanted box in \RNr[n] spanned by the vectors ( \Vect{x}_1 , \dots , \Vect{x}_n ).
Already the following two examples illustrate the simple beauty of this result.

li.para: The vectors \Vect{x} = (4320,89) and \Vect{y} = (4310,87) span a parallelogram whose area is \Abs{375840 - 383590} = 383590 - 375840.
The pair of vectors ( \Vect{x} , \Vect{y} ) represents the negative or clockwise orientation of the plane.
The vectors \Vect{x} = (3,-2,1), \Vect{y} = (7,4,0), \Vect{z} = (-1,3,6) span a slanted box in \RNr[3] whose volume is 181.
The ordered triple of vectors ( \Vect{x} , \Vect{y} , \Vect{z} ) represents the positive or right hand orientation of the \RNr[3].
